Problem:
Consider a system subject to periodic external force, modeled by the differential equation \\(\\ddot{x} + p\\dot{x} + qx = f(t)\\) where p and q are constants and \\(f(t)\\) represents the forcing term. We examine the effect of applying a transformation defined by the function \\( g(x) = Ax^2 \\) to the state x, where A is a constant.

If the initial state \\( x_0 \\) is square-transformed by \\( g(x) \\) and then allowed to evolve under the given differential equation without further intervention, will the state \\( x(T) \\) at time T be equivalent to evolving \\( x_0 \\) directly under the same conditions?
Explanation: The squaring transformation \\( g(x) = Ax^2 \\) modifies the initial condition, which in turn affects the entire trajectory of the system. Consequently, the trajectory starting from \\(Ax_0^2\\) will not match the trajectory from \\( x_0 \\), as the system's behavior is highly sensitive to initial conditions.
